Selected Answer: B
B because although option A can work, it requires at least one person to own all the files and share with the rest of the team. A shared drive makes more sense in this case

questions.question_text: Your organization has hired a recruiting firm that is responsible for reviewing resumes and job descriptions of prospective summer interns. Employees at your organization need to collaborate with the external firm on these documents. You must set permissions and ensure the recruiting firm employees can't remove the files. What should you do?

choices.B: Create a Shared Drive and grant Contributor access to the HR team.
choices.D: Create a Shared Drive and grant Content Manager access to the HR team.
choices.A: Create a Google Group, add the HR team, and create a shared folder for content storage and editing.
choices.C: Enable client-side encryption for the organizational unit (OU) for which the HR team are members.

choices.A: Confirm that your organization is set to the rapid release option to ensure that your users receive new features when Google releases them.
choices.B: Do nothing. No extra configuration is needed as all Workspace customers receive new features at the same time.
choices.D: Enable the new feature in a Workspace Sandbox organization, and roll out to users only after testing.
choices.C: Confirm that your organization is set to the scheduled release option to ensure that your users receive new features when Google releases them.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
A- Rapid Release gives you earlier access to new features by several weeks.

Selected Answer: A
Since the organization size is small opting into rapid release option is the ideal way.

https://support.google.com/a/answer/172177?hl=en#:~:text=You%20can%20choose%20to%20have,they're%20launched%20to%20consumers.

questions.question_text: You work for a small organization and are planning to deploy an upcoming Google Workspace feature. You want users to have access to the feature as soon as possible. What should you do?

You work at a financial institution with strict security requirements. You have been asked by the head of IT security to enforce the policy that allows access to Google Workspace services only from devices that are within the company's network. What should you do?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
Since the restriction to happen based on device, Context-Aware Access with IP address enforcement is the ideal way

https://support.google.com/a/answer/12642752?hl=en&ref_topic=9262521&sjid=1370437735239910488-AP

choices.C: Enable context-aware access (CAA) for all employees, and add the IP subnet as a context condition.
choices.B: Enable context-aware access (CAA) for all employees, and add the location as a context condition.
choices.A: Ask everyone to use Chromebooks in your organization and deploy network certificates.
choices.D: Enable client-side encryption (CSE) for all employees.

choices.C: Create a group of administrative assistants. Enable delegated access to the mailbox of the CEO for that group.
choices.A: Provide the executive administrative assistants with the account password of the CEO.
choices.B: Enable users to specify what sender information is included in delegated messages sent from their account.
choices.D: Log into the Gmail account of the CEO. Set up and share two separate email aliases.

questions.question_text: You work for an international organization and your CEO frequently travels to other countries. You need to enable email access and configure the account for multiple administrative assistants. What should you do?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
delegated access makes sense
C makes sense, others does not.

C is my choice...

https://apps.google.com/supportwidget/articlehome?hl=en&article_url=https%3A%2F%2Fsupport.google.com%2Fa%2Fanswer%2F11946994%3Fhl%3Den&assistant_id=generic-unu&product_context=11946994&product_name=UnuFlow&trigger_context=a

Using email delegation
A single Google account can support up to 1000 delegates. To avoid impacting account performance, we recommend allowing a maximum of 40 concurrent users.
Google Workspace admins control whether messages sent by delegates include the email address of both the account owner and the delegate, or only the account owner.
Google Groups can be added as account delegates. One Group counts as a single delegate for that account.
Email aliases don't support delegates because an alias isn’t a Google Account.

questions.question_text: Your team uses Google Drive for collaborating with external companies and partners. A sensitive project with an external organization is about to begin. You are creating the new labels for the project. You must ensure that all labeled documents have the label visible to everyone who has access to the project files. What should you do?

choices.B: Create Drive labels and add the users from the external organization to your domain.
choices.C: Create Drive labels and add the permissions for all users in the project, including the external users, to view these labels.
choices.A: Create Drive labels and a separate Shared Drive for the project.
choices.D: Create Drive labels and apply data protection rules to all project file.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
Agree with. C

Selected Answer: C
C-By default, everyone in your organization can view and apply labels. Edit label permissions to control who can view, apply, edit field values, and search by the label. For example:

To allow users outside your organization, or groups containing outside users, to view and use labels, add these users and groups under Advanced permissions.

Também entendo que a resposta adequada ao cenário seja "C", apesar da documentação citar:

https://support.google.com/a/answer/13127870?hl=en

Step 5. (Optional) Use labels to classify and protect data
If your Google Workspace edition supports data loss prevention (DLP) for Drive, you can set up rules to automatically apply labels to content created by certain users (data classification) and to block sharing of content with specific labels (DLP).
